author: CannaVestments
body:
This is unfortunately a perfect example of someone misunderstanding a financial statement. Aphria is not even remotely close to "positive free cash flow from operations". Turning to page 5 of Aphria's two most recently quarterly financials: 

[https://aphriainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Aphria-Inc\_Q2\_2020\_Financial-Statements.pdf](https://aphriainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Aphria-Inc_Q2_2020_Financial-Statements.pdf)

[https://aphriainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Aphria-Inc\_Q3-2020\_Consolidated-Financial-Statements.pdf](https://aphriainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Aphria-Inc_Q3-2020_Consolidated-Financial-Statements.pdf)

Look for the section called "**Cash used in operating activities"** and you can see how they go from their net gain for the period to the actual cash flow figure by removing all non-cash adjustments that are included in net gain/loss. APH had -$71.23M in cash used from operating activities through fiscal Q2 and now are at -$124.37M in cash used from operating activities through fiscal Q3, meaning they posted a $53.14M operating cash flow loss on the quarter. This is part of the reason why you see cash dropping from the start of the quarter to the end, with the capex and financing activities added in.

Now you compare this to GTI's 10k they just posted: [https://d18rn0p25nwr6d.cloudfront.net/CIK-0001795139/d711db76-ee78-4a81-99d2-c85271bd8acf.pdf](https://d18rn0p25nwr6d.cloudfront.net/CIK-0001795139/d711db76-ee78-4a81-99d2-c85271bd8acf.pdf)

Page 9 of the pdf and you'll see the same basic page of numbers for GTI titled "**Cash flow from operating activities."** At the bottom, you'll see a positive $27,048,097 in "**Net Cash provided by operating activities"** after all the non-cash adjustments. This is what it means to have "positive operating cash flow." Now continue down this page to add in capital expenditures and financing activities, and you'll end up with "**net increase (decrease) in cash and cash equivalents"** of positive **$24,854,620,** reflecting positive free cash flow as well. Hence why you see the **cash and cash equivalents** rise from **$46,667,334** from the start of Q1 to **$71,521,954** at the end of Q1. 

GTI cash level went up because they had positive free cash flow from operations. Aph cash went down because they had negative cash flow from operations.
